lens.lens_summary: Reveals how friction-heavy moments in the guest journey could be redesigned as lightweight microinteractions, particularly around pricing transparency, profile completion, and stay-by-stay reviews.

discovery.what_this_lens_reveals: Tapper is a first-time Split Lease user trying to understand the platform's unique part-time model. The microinteractions lens reveals that initial platform comprehension is a critical trigger moment‚Äîguests need immediate clarity on what makes Split Lease different without extensive education. Robert's explanation becomes the 'feedback' layer that makes the hidden 'rules' visible.

user_state.knowledge_level: Zero prior knowledge of Split Lease. Tapper says 'this is my first time learning about split lease' (line 01:42)
user_state.commitment_level: Exploratory‚Äîhas already responded to a listing but doesn't understand the platform mechanics yet
user_state.data_available: Phone number, email, has already inquired about a specific listing, budget constraints ($2,500/month), has a dog, works at Bryant Park holiday booth

reasons: Confusion about per-bedroom vs whole-unit pricing
Uncertainty about what 'part-time' vs 'full-time' means
Lack of trust signals for a new, unfamiliar platform model

This confusion happens because the platform's pricing rules aren't surfaced clearly before the trigger (inquiry).

key_quotes.relevance: Shows the discovery phase needs to front-load the unique value proposition and constraints of the platform. Guest is learning basic platform rules through trial-and-error rather than upfront design.

key_quotes.relevance: Critical design principle: the pricing structure and per-bedroom vs full-unit distinction should be visible BEFORE the guest clicks into a listing or submits an inquiry.

key_quotes.quote: The difference between a product we love and a product we tolerate are often the microinteractions we have with it.
key_quotes.relevance: First impressions are made of these small moments‚Äîpricing clarity, platform model explanation, filtering logic. If these microinteractions are confusing, guests won't trust the platform.

discovery.review_relevance: Discovery affects review willingness by establishing trust. If a guest's early microinteractions are confusing (pricing, platform model), they enter the journey skeptical. This skepticism carries forward‚Äîguests who feel misled early are less likely to leave generous reviews later. Conversely, transparent upfront communication creates goodwill that makes later review requests feel like fair reciprocity.

The microinteractions lens reveals that search filters are actually a series of cascading rules that need smart defaults and visible feedback to prevent guest frustration.

search.review_relevance: Search quality affects review expectations. If a guest finds the perfect listing easily (good microinteractions), they arrive with positive sentiment that makes them more generous reviewers. If search is frustrating, they arrive already annoyed‚Äîand more likely to focus on negatives in reviews. The search phase also sets expectations: if filters accurately represent what's available, the guest's reality matches expectations, reducing negative review risk.

listing_evaluation.review_relevance: This phase directly shapes review sentiment. If a guest feels misled about pricing during evaluation but proceeds anyway, they arrive at the listing with negative bias. If reality exceeds expectations (the unit is better than the listing suggested), reviews are positive. If reality falls short (photos were misleading, price felt deceptive), reviews are harsh. The listing evaluation phase sets the expectation baseline against which all future experiences are measured.

proposal_creation.what_this_lens_reveals: Proposal creation is a high-friction form-filling exercise that could be streamlined into a near-effortless microinteraction. Robert explicitly tells Tapper to complete his profile and rental application, but this creates unnecessary steps between interest and commitment. The microinteractions lens reveals this should be a single-flow experience with smart defaults.

proposal_creation.review_relevance: Proposal creation is where guests begin building their 'host profile'‚Äîthe information hosts will see throughout the relationship. If this process feels cumbersome, guests are less likely to complete it thoroughly, resulting in weaker trust foundations. Weak trust = lower review participation later. Additionally, this phase establishes a pattern: if Split Lease asks for lots of manual work upfront, guests will resist later requests (like reviews). If the proposal flow is effortless, guests feel the platform respects their time‚Äîmaking them more likely to reciprocate with review effort later.

The lens reveals negotiation could be a guided, low-friction process rather than manual back-and-forth.

negotiation.review_relevance: Negotiation quality affects the power dynamic guests perceive. If negotiation feels fair and transparent (clear reasons for counters, data-driven suggestions), guests feel respected and are more likely to leave balanced reviews. If negotiation feels arbitrary or opaque, guests feel powerless‚Äîleading to either no reviews (disengagement) or negative reviews (resentment). The negotiation phase also sets expectations for ongoing communication: if it's smooth here, guests expect smooth review exchanges later.

By framing reviews as an expected, normal part of the lease lifecycle (not an optional favor), the platform increases participation. The microinteractions principle 'Long Loops' applies: design the acceptance confirmation to prime the first review, and each review to prime the next.

If it falls short, they're already composing negative feedback mentally. active_lease.review_relevance: Active lease is THE review phase. Every design decision here affects review volume. Key microinteraction opportunities: (1) Trigger: Auto-prompt at stay end, ideally when cleaning photos are submitted (guest is already engaged with the platform). (2) Rules: Pre-populate with prior ratings if unchanged. Offer 'Same as last time' one-tap option. Limit to 2-3 questions. (3) Feedback: Immediate confirmation, no follow-up requests. Show review live on host's profile. (4) Loops: First review explains why it matters and walks through questions. Subsequent reviews are progressively simpler‚Äîby review 5+, it's one tap. This design could 10x review volume vs traditional post-transaction surveys.

natural_review_moments: Immediately after cleaning photos are submitted (guest is already engaged, has phone out, stay is fresh in mind)
When guest receives 'Next stay starts tomorrow' notification (contextual reminder, easy to reflect on prior stay)
At the end of the lease, as a summary review (less frequent but allows reflection on overall relationship)
When host completes their review (reciprocity trigger‚Äî'Your host reviewed you, share your thoughts too')
microinteraction_opportunities: TRIGGER: System-initiated prompt at stay-end (don't rely on guest remembering to initiate). Tie to cleaning photo submission or next-stay notification‚Äîmoments when guest is already using the app.

RULES: Pre-populate ratings from last stay if guest-host pairing is recurring. Offer 'Same as last time ‚úì' one-tap option. Limit to 2-3 core questions (star rating, brief comment, issue flag). More depth optional but not required.

FEEDBACK: Immediate confirmation ('Thanks! Your review is live.'). Show review's impact ('You've helped 12 future guests.'). NO follow-up requests (no 'share this' or 'rate us' secondary prompts‚Äîcreates fatigue).

LOOPS: First review (stay 1) explains the system and why reviews matter. Reviews 2-4 are standard flow. Reviews 5+ offer accelerated options ('Same as last time? ‚úì'). By review 10, it should be a single tap. Long loops make reviews progressively easier.

SIGNATURE MOMENT: Full-screen review interface immediately after cleaning photo submission‚Äîno navigation, no separate page. Rate with one tap, add comment if desired, submit. Feels instant and integrated, not like a separate task.
friction_reducers: Pre-populate ratings from prior stay (guest just confirms or adjusts)
Embed review prompt in existing workflow (cleaning photo flow, arrival notification) rather than separate task
Limit to 2-3 questions max‚Äîstar rating, one-line comment, optional issue flag
Offer 'Same as last time' one-tap option for recurring stays
NO login required (if guest is already in app for other reason)
Show character count and real-time preview to reduce editing anxiety
Allow skip/defer ('Remind me later') without guilt or repeated nagging
volume_multipliers: Reviews per stay (not per lease): A 3-month, 4-nights/week lease = ~12 stays = 12 review opportunities from ONE guest-host pairing. Current platforms only get 1 review per pairing. This is a 12x multiplier IF the review microinteraction is frictionless enough.
Long loops reduce friction over time: First review takes 60 seconds. Tenth review takes 5 seconds. This maintains high participation across all 12 stays rather than dropping off after the first few.
Reciprocity trigger: When host reviews guest, guest gets notification ('Your host shared feedback‚Äîyou can too'). Social norm of reciprocity increases participation.
Contextual timing: Reviews triggered when guest is already engaged (submitting cleaning photos, receiving next-stay reminder) have higher completion rates than random prompts.
Visible impact: Show guests how many people read their reviews or were helped by them. This gamifies participation without being obnoxious.

Pre-populated drafts: If a guest hasn't reviewed after 48 hours, send a draft review pre-filled with their prior ratings and say 'Does this still match your experience? Confirm or edit.' This reduces activation energy from 100% to 10%.
